Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) governed by the equation \\( z'(t) = Cz(t) \\), where C is a constant complex number. We explore the effect of the Laplace transformation on this function, defined by \\( L[z](s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \\), focusing on how this transform influences the behavior and conclusions about the system.

Does applying the Laplace transformation to \\( z(t) \\), followed by allowing the system to evolve according to \\( z'(t) = Cz(t) \\) without any intervention, change the expression of the transformed function compared to directly transforming the system's output at any given time?
Explanation: The Laplace transform of the solution to \\( z'(t) = Cz(t) \\) will be the same regardless of when it is applied because the transformation itself does not alter the differential equation governing the system. The transform just captures the behavior across the entire evolution without altering the time dynamics.
